Dear Denise Crawford:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
3/17/23. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan
is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all of
the following information prior to employment or at the
time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
2

provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse
or child neglect. The documentation shall be completed
not more than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
Ten of ten new hire employee files reviewed did not have documentation the
Central Registry Check was completed prior to employment at the facility.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to employment,
that each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1 year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the
last verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
One of ten new hire employee files reviewed did not have documentation that the
Tuberculosis screening was completed prior to employment.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Licensing Inspection 12/17/21 with an approved CAP on 1/19/22.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Develop a system/process to ensure all employment requirements are completed
at the time of hire.
• Add a specific section for progress on each goal in treatment plans.
• Ensure each report is only 90-days in length by developing a system to track the
days.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Develop electronic record keeping for all youth files.
3

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan related to the
Special Investigation 2022C0214023 dated 5/25/22. The initial complaint was
unfounded but an additional finding was made. Reviewing Youth A’s Residential
Service plan it was found the plan was lacking basic information that is required.
The facility’s CAP was approved on 7/7/22 and involved the development of a
specialist to review all key requirments with the treatment plans to ensure accuracy.
Chief Administrator was to develop a review form and template to assist in the
development of the treatment plans. The faciltiy will also schedule reviews of the
treatment plans for initial and updated treatment plans. Although this investigation
involved treatment plans the issues were not the same as found in the Renewal
Inspection dated 12/17/21. The facility’s corrective action plan compliance is
monitored quarterly and no further issues have been identified.
The other CAP submitted was in regards to the facility’s Renewal Inspection for
2021. There were six violations for this review and the facility submitted a CAP
which was approved on 1/19/22.
Financial Overview
The yearly financial audit was completed on 4/13/2023 and there are no financial
concerns identified based on the facility’s budget and financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator documents the efforts and progress they made in following their
CAP from the Renewal inspection and special investigation that occurred during the
period under review. Chief Administrator also addressed the issue of the facility not
obtaining the Central Registry Clearance prior to employment. The issue of
placement of a MDHHS youth (facility is not contracted) at the facility with a
MDHHS providing a future contract was outlined and the youth was moved by
MDHHS 25 days after placement at the facility.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff reported being supported by administration and believe they are providing
“best practice” for the care of the youth. Staff report receiving training to help them
4

understand and deal with the youth in the program. The two-youth struggle with
communication but presented as doing well and liking their placement. Both
appeared relaxed and in happy moods.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was in excellent condition and all rooms were furnished appropriately.
The menu was present and there was an ample supply of both frozen and fresh
food including fruit and vegetables. All fire extinguishers had been inspected as
required and there was both cold and hot running water in all bathrooms and
kitchen. All water drained appropriately. Cleaning supplies were locked up as was
the utility room. All required posting were present, and the facility has both a
landline and cell phone in working order. All rooms were of appropriate
temperature.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
